# init(locale:)

**Initializer**

Creates a floating-point format style that uses the given locale.

## Declaration

```swift
init(locale: Locale = .autoupdatingCurrent)
```

## Parameters

- **locale**: The locale to use when formatting or parsing floating-point values. Defaults to [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Locale/autoupdatingCurrent].

## Discussion

Create a [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/FloatingPointFormatStyle] when you intend to apply a given style to multiple floating-point values. The following example creates a style that uses the `en_US` locale, which uses three-based grouping and comma separators. It then applies this style to all the [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/Double] values in an array.

```swift
let enUSstyle = FloatingPointFormatStyle<Double>(locale: Locale(identifier: "en_US"))
let nums = [100.1, 1000.2, 10000.3, 100000.4, 1000000.5]
let formattedNums = nums.map { enUSstyle.format($0) } // ["100.1", "1,000.2", "10,000.3", "100,000.4", "1,000,000.5"]

```

To format a single integer, you can use the [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/BinaryFloatingPoint] instance method [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/BinaryFloatingPoint/formatted(_:)-83x4n], passing in an instance of [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/FloatingPointFormatStyle].
